Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Resolving an ancient radiation: gingers, phylogenies, and fossils.
Award.AbstractNarration:
The order Zingiberales is a diverse group of economically and ecologically important tropical plants including banana, gingers, bird-of-paradise, and canna. This project examines the genetic, morphological, and ecological evolution of Zingiberales over geologic time scales. Morphological data from living and fossil species will be combined with DNA data to reconstruct evolutionary relationships among species and the timing of important evolutionary events. The geographical distribution of living and fossil species and changes in their ecology through time will then be examined to understand how these plants have adapted to different regions and climates through time.

The integration of multiple lines of evidence from fossil and modern data is needed in order to understand evolutionary drivers and responses, current and historic biodiversity, and how modern ecosystems have been formed; all of which give us insight to the current patterns of biodiversity and the ability to predict future evolutionary patterns and ecosystem processes. The Zingiberales serve as a model for this type of study due to their ecological importance today and the presence of an extensive fossil record. In addition, because they are tropical and subtropical plants, they will help us understand the biology of a warming world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major intellectual outcome of this research was the development of the most comprehensive understanding of evolution across the order Zingiberales, providing a context for the physiological, morphological and geographic diversification of this charasmatic tropical lineage.  We developed a strong and well supported phylogeny for Zingiberales that includes genomic data for living species and morphological data for both living and fossil taxa. These data matrices alone provide raw material for future studies into molecular evolution and organismal diversification of a major tropical lineage with important environmental and ecological interactions.  Our data and phylogenetic results also allowed us to explore the evolution of leaf, fruit and seed traits through time and during different climatic periods.  With the phylogenetic foundation in place, we can now explore how different environmental conditions have driven processes such as diversification, speciation and extinction during the past 100my of Zingiberales evolution.  A dated phylogeny of Zingiberales using fossils confirms a rapid radiation of the order occuring in central europe, followed by lineage expansion into Asia, Africa and the Americas as tropical climates dominated these areas. Specific seed and embryo characterisitcs correlate with environmental adaptation rather than taxonomic/phylogenetic affiliation, indicating that certain key traits are important for successful adaptation to novel climates over time. Two postdoctoral fellows and two graduate students were trained in integrative evolutionary biology and 4 undergraduates were trained in comparative phylogenetics, two of whom have gone on to graduate school in evolutionary biology. An exhibit on the importance of fossils to understanding evolution and the diversity of the Zingiberales and their role in global biodiversity was developed and displayed at the University of Michigan and will be presented at Cornell University during the coming year.
